A long time ago I worked for a company that made Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometers. All new employees went through the two week customer training course to learn how the machines worked. In our class one of the customers was an evidence tech from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police - I was sitting next to an actual Mountie! Cool! One of the attachments for the spectrometer was a microscope - the Mountie had brought along a sample paint chip with three layers of different color paint. We focused the microscope on each layer and ran the results through the database to identify the brand, color and year of each layer!

For even deeper analysis, we worked with a GC / Mass Spec to split up the sample by boiling point and molecular weight. The boiled off results were deposited on a cold plate in a labyrinth pattern and then the spectrometer sampled along the path to further analyze the components. Those were fun days working with some pretty cool machinery :-)

Up until now I found this series very unclear. It is too focused on definitions and difficult wordings (I still have no clue about esters/carboneel or whatever, just show the damn molecule or highlight the part you are talking about). Related, why not give a proper example with high resolution mass spec: C2H3NS vs C2H3NO2, both 73, but a little different in the numbers behind the comma/period. Now that whole part was useless, as most people will not know that when adding O2 to a C atom, the mass of CO2 is not 1 C-mass plus 2 O-masses. The FTIR part goes really wrong. The y-axis is in transmittance, so not the intensity of absorption but the inverse. The unit is cm-1 not wavenumber (inverse cm or reciprocal cm). Saying that something has higher wavenumbers is just bad grammar. 'this spring has higher forces' or 'I measure 300 currents'. I also loved that sometimes parts of the FTIR spectra are cut out and sometimes not. As you are not labeling any peak, CO2/H2O peaks are irrelevant anyway. And the part of the fingerprint region was so unclear: fingerprint is difficult to interpret and therefore you look at other locations like 1000-3000 cm-1 area. Sadly this part contains the same fingerprint region.
